August 25, 1985: Fiction
SKELETON CREW, by Stephen King. (Putnam, $18.95.) Twenty-two tales of
horror set in contemporary America.
THE FOURTH DEADLY SIN, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam, $17.95.) Which of
six suspects murdered a saintly New York psychiatrist?
THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom Clancy. (Naval Institute Press,
$14.95.) A Lithuanian submarine driver defects to the United States with the
Soviet Union's most advanced nuclear secrets.
LUCKY, by Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The heiress of a crime
lord takes on the heiress of a shipping tycoon in fashionable spots all over the
world.
THE TWO MRS. GRENVILLES, by Dominick Dunne. (Crown, $14.95.) Romance,
scandal and murder in New York's high society.
THE CIDER HOUSE RULES, by John Irving. (Morrow, $18.95.) Life in a Maine
orphanage earlier in this century.
JUBAL SACKETT, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $16.95.) In this forerunner to the
17-volume Sackett saga, a restless explorer scouts the 17th-century American
wilderness.
LONESOME DOVE, by Larry McMurtry. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The Old
West seen larger than life.
IF TOMORROW COMES, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $17.95.) A young woman
destroys the crime lords who got her an undeserved prison term.
HOLD THE DREAM, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Continuing
the family saga begun in ''A Woman of Substance.''
THE LOVER, by Marguerite Duras. (Pantheon, $11.95.) The sexual initiation of an
adolescent girl by a rich Chinese in Saigon in the 30's.
FALL FROM GRACE, by Larry Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Machinations
by spies, double agents and a beautiful woman on the eve of D-Day.
TOO MUCH, TOO SOON, by Jacqueline Briskin. (Putnam, $17.95.) Three sisters
find their destinies bound by an obsession with the same man.
FAMILY ALBUM, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $16.95.) A married couple with five
children cope with the crises of modern-day America.
INSIDE, OUTSIDE, by Herman Wouk. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) A traditionalist Jew's
quest for identity in glittery contemporary America.
August 25, 1985
Non-Fiction
YEAGER: An Autobiography, by Chuck Yeager and Leo Janos. (Bantam, $17.95.)
The story of the first man to fly faster than sound.
IACOCCA: An Autobiography, by Lee Iacocca with William Novak. (Bantam,
$19.95.) The rise of an immigrants' son to top jobs at Ford and Chrysler.
A PASSION FOR EXCELLENCE, by Tom Peters and Nancy Austin. (Random
House, $19.95.) Ways to achieve distinction in management.
SMART WOMEN, FOOLISH CHOICES, by Connell Cowan and Melvyn Kinder.
(Clarkson N. Potter, $13.95.) Two clinical psychologists analyze modern women's
efforts to find acceptable men.
THE MICK, by Mickey Mantle with Herb Gluck. (Doubleday, $15.95.) The
autobiography of the New York Yankee baseball star.
CONFESSIONS OF A HOOKER, by Bob Hope with Dwayne Netland. (Doubleday,
$17.95.) Memories of more than 50 years of golfing, by the comedian.
MARTINA, by Martina Navratilova with George Vecsey. (Knopf, $16.95.) The
autobiography of the Czechoslovak-born tennis champion.
NUTCRACKER, by Shana Alexander. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Treachery, mystery
and high society in the 1978 murder of a Mormon multimillionaire.
THE AMATEURS, by David Halberstam. (Morrow, $14.95.) Four American men
seek the 1984 Olympic single-sculling championship.
HAMMER OF THE GODS: The Led Zeppelin Saga, by Stephen Davis. (Morrow,
$15.95.) The British heavy metal group's boisterous tours of the 1970's.
FUNNY MONEY, by Mark Singer. (Knopf, $15.95.) The scandal surrounding the
1982 collapse of the Penn Square Bank in Oklahoma City.
THE GRASSHOPPER TRAP, by Patrick F. McManus. (Holt, $13.95.) Amusing
pieces about pursuing pleasures in the great outdoors.
THE DANGEROUS SUMMER, by Ernest Hemingway. (Scribners, $17.95.) A
chronicle of the Spanish bullfight season of 1959.
MOUNTBATTEN, by Philip Ziegler. (Knopf, $24.95.) The authorized biography of
the British nobleman, diplomat and naval hero.
AT MOTHER'S REQUEST, by Jonathan Coleman. (Atheneum, $19.95.) Another
account of the murder case recounted in ''Nutcracker'' (see No. 8).
THE BRIDGE ACROSS FOREVER, by Richard Bach. (Morrow, $16.95.) The
